DOC.brief_summary: Chest tubes are used routinely although preliminary studies demonstrate the feasibility and safety of intraoperative chest drain removal. Previous studies are however either retrospective or mainly concerning benign disease. Hypothesis: Participants treated without post-operative chest tube after thoracoscopic wedge resection have less pain, better pulmonary function and similar complication profile than participants treated with standard post-operative chest tube, and could possibly be discharged earlier.
DOC.brief_title: ThOracoscopic Wedge Resection Treated With Chest Tube Removal Intraoperatively
DOC.criteria: Elective thoracoscopic wedge resection Speaks and understands Danish FEV1 >= 60% of expected Tumor <= 2 cm in diameter Tumor <= 3 cm from visceral pleura Adhesions <= 20% of lung surface Absence of bullous/emphysematous changes Absence of coagulopathy Absence of air leak on intraoperative sealing test Lacking ability to adhere to protocol Planned intraoperative frozen section with possible lobectomy Previously included in current study Preoperative chest tube requirement Condition precluding standard analgesic regime (eg. ulcer, heart failure, kidney failure, allergy) Preagnancy or lactation Ipsilateral thoracic surgery within previous 8 weeks Undergoing treatment with steroid (disregarding nasal or inhalational steroid) Chronic pain requiring treatment
